channel.title: NYT > Technology
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Elizabeth Holmes Is Sentenced to More Than 11 Years for Theranos Fraud
item.description: Ms. Holmes was convicted in January of four counts of wire fraud for deceiving investors with claims about her blood testing start-up Theranos.
item.dc:creator: Erin Griffith
item.media:description: Elizabeth Holmes with her partner, Billy Evans, at the federal courthouse in San Jose, Calif., on Friday. She was convicted of four charges of fraud in January.

item.title: Elon Musk’s Twitter Teeters on the Edge After Another 1,200 Leave
item.description: Mr. Musk sent emails on Friday asking to learn about Twitter’s underlying technology as key infrastructure teams have been decimated.
item.dc:creator: Ryan Mac, Mike Isaac and Kellen Browning
item.media:credit: Jason Henry for The New York Times
item.media:description: Twitter’s headquarters in San Francisco. So many workers have left that Twitter users have questioned whether the site would survive.

item.title: Ticketmaster’s Parent Company Said to Face Justice Department Investigation
item.description: The inquiry predates the botched presale of Taylor Swift tickets this week and is said to focus on whether Live Nation has abused its power in the live music industry.
item.dc:creator: David McCabe and Ben Sisario
item.media:credit: Krista Schlueter for The New York Times
item.media:description: An overwhelming number of presale ticket buyers for Taylor Swift’s concert tour crashed Ticketmaster’s systems this week.

item.title: FTX’s Unraveling and Elon Musk’s Ultimatum to Twitter Employees
item.description: Sam Bankman-Fried’s DMs go public, and Congress announces an investigation. Tech’s nightmare November continues.
item.dc:creator: Kevin Roose, Casey Newton, Davis Land, Paula Szuchman, Sophia Lanman, Dan Powell, Marion Lozano and Elisheba Ittoop
item.media:credit: Photo Illustration: The New York Times; Image: Dado Ruvic/Reuters

item.title: What Employees Does Twitter Need, Anyway?
item.description: The many departures have set off a wave of hand-wringing about whether the site can continue to operate well.
item.dc:creator: Cecilia Kang
item.media:credit: Jason Henry for The New York Times
item.media:description: Twitter employees are walking off the job this week.

item.title: How to Download Your Twitter Archive
item.description: Those worried about the service’s longevity can preserve their tweets, media and direct messages.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Victor
item.media:description: Mass resignations at Twitter have prompted concerns about the future of the social media site.

item.title: Resignations Roil Twitter as Elon Musk Tries Persuading Some Workers to Stay
item.description: Mr. Musk, Twitter’s new owner, had given employees a Thursday deadline to decide whether to leave or stay “to build a breakthrough Twitter 2.0.”
item.dc:creator: Ryan Mac, Mike Isaac and David McCabe
item.media:description: Elon Musk and his advisers held meetings with some Twitter workers to try to stop them from leaving.

item.title: Elizabeth Holmes to Be Sentenced in Fraud Trial
item.description: Ms. Holmes, founder of the failed blood testing start-up Theranos, is scheduled to learn her fate on Friday. She faces a maximum of 20 years in prison.
item.dc:creator: Erin Griffith
item.media:description: More than 100 letters have been filed in support of Elizabeth Holmes, who left court last month with her partner, Billy Evans.

item.title: Children’s Groups Want F.T.C. to Ban ‘Unfair’ Online Manipulation of Kids
item.description: Children’s privacy and health experts pressed regulators to prohibit video games and social networks from using attention-hacking techniques on youngsters.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Singer

item.title: New FTX CEO Calls the Crypto Exchange’s Corporate Control a ‘Complete Failure’
item.description: “This situation is unprecedented,” said John J. Ray III, who helped manage Enron after its collapse in an accounting fraud scandal in 2001.
item.dc:creator: David Yaffe-Bellany
item.media:credit: Erika P. Rodriguez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sam Bankman-Fried, the former chief executive of the cryptocurrency exchange FTX, which collapsed into bankruptcy.

item.title: Meet Your New Corporate Office Mate: A ‘Brainless’ Robot
item.description: Naver, a South Korean internet firm, is trying to introduce robots into the world of cubicles and conference rooms without making employees uncomfortable.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon and Daisuke Wakabayashi
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: A robot making a delivery at Naver’s offices on the outskirts of Seoul.

item.title: SpaceX Employees Say They Were Fired for Speaking Up About Elon Musk
item.description: Charges filed with federal regulators accuse the company of retaliating against eight workers over an open letter critical of the chief executive.
item.dc:creator: Noam Scheiber and Ryan Mac
item.media:credit: Jenna Schoenefeld for The New York Times
item.media:description: Paige Holland-Thielen, left, and Tom Moline say they were fired from SpaceX after helping to organize a letter calling on the company to condemn the Twitter activity of Elon Musk, its founder and chief executive.

item.title: NASA Blazes a Path Back to the Moon With Artemis I Rocket Launch
item.description: The uncrewed flight of the giant Space Launch System on Wednesday began a new era of spaceflight amid a debate over how to finance rocket development.
item.dc:creator: Kenneth Chang
item.media:description: After a couple of last minute hiccups, the Artemis I mission’s rocket, carrying the uncrewed Orion space capsule, launched from the Kennedy Space Center for the moon in the wee hours of Wednesday.

item.title: Elon Musk Gives Twitter Employees a Deadline to Stay or Leave
item.description: Mr. Musk said that workers would need to answer through an online form by late Thursday and that those who stayed would be “working long hours at high intensity.”
item.dc:creator: Kate Conger
item.media:credit: Jason Henry for The New York Times
item.media:description: Elon Musk gave Twitter employees a deadline of 5 p.m. Eastern time on Thursday to decide if they wanted to work for him.

item.title: Musk Testifies in Trial Over His Tesla Compensation Package
item.description: The billionaire chief executive testified about a multibillion-dollar compensation package the electric car company’s board put in place in 2018.
item.dc:creator: Jack Ewing, Isabella Simonetti and Peter Eavis

item.title: Elon Musk Heads to Court to Defend His Billions in Tesla Pay
item.description: A shareholder is asking the court to void a 2018 compensation package that has paid the chief executive nearly $50 billion.
item.dc:creator: Peter Eavis, Jack Ewing and Isabella Simonetti
item.media:description: Elon Musk, Tesla’s chief executive, leaving the Delaware Court of Chancery in Wilmington last year. He is expected to return on Wednesday.

item.title: Worried About Your Twitter Account? Here’s What to Do
item.description: Don’t delete your account just yet. Elon Musk’s takeover can teach us valuable lessons about our relationship with social networks.
item.dc:creator: Brian X. Chen

item.title: Elon Musk Fires Twitter Employees Who Criticized Him
item.description: Mr. Musk, who is rapidly transforming the social media company, also has cut its contractor work force.
item.dc:creator: Kate Conger, Ryan Mac and Mike Isaac
item.media:description: Elon Musk, Twitter’s new owner, ordered the firings of nearly two dozen employees who had pushed back publicly and privately against him.

item.title: FTX’s In-House Performance Coach Is Just as Surprised as You Are
item.description: George K. Lerner, a psychiatrist who has worked at the collapsed crypto exchange FTX since last year, said he had no knowledge of wrongdoing at the firm.
item.dc:creator: Kevin Roose
item.media:credit: Erika P. Rodriguez for The New York Times
item.media:description: The headquarters of FTX are in the Bahamas, where their in-house coach lives.

item.title: FTX Could Owe More Than 1 Million Creditors
item.description: In a court filing on Monday, the cryptocurrency exchange said it was in touch with “dozens” of regulators across the world.
item.dc:creator: David Yaffe-Bellany
item.media:description: The collapsed crypto exchange FTX and its related businesses could owe money to more than one million people.

item.title: Voter Fraud Claims Are Not as Prominent as in 2020
item.description: False narratives failed to take root on Election Day. But several Republican candidates pointed to election fraud as their prospects worsened.
item.dc:creator: Stuart A. Thompson
item.media:credit: Rebecca Noble for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mark Finchem, center, questioned the integrity of the result in his race for Arizona secretary of state. “They are screwing with the election counts,” he wrote on Twitter.

item.title: How Sam Bankman-Fried’s FTX Crypto Empire Collapsed
item.description: Mr. Bankman-Fried said in an interview that he had expanded too fast and failed to see warning signs. But he shared few details about his handling of FTX customers’ funds.
item.dc:creator: David Yaffe-Bellany
item.media:credit: Erika P. Rodriguez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sam Bankman-Fried, who was a cryptocurrency billionaire, lost nearly his entire fortune over the past week.

item.title: Google Agrees to $392 Million Privacy Settlement With 40 States
item.description: Under the agreement, which state attorneys general said was the largest U.S. internet privacy settlement, Google must also make its location-tracking practices clearer to users.
item.dc:creator: Cecilia Kang
item.media:description: The attorneys general said Google’s practices violated state consumer protection laws that forbid companies to mislead and deceive consumers.

item.title: Amazon Is Said to Plan to Lay Off Approximately 10,000 Employees
item.description: The job cuts of approximately 10,000, which would start as soon as this week, would focus on the company’s devices organization, retail division and human resources.
item.dc:creator: Karen Weise
item.media:credit: Miles Fortune for The New York Times
item.media:description: The job cuts at Amazon would represent roughly 3 percent of its corporate employees and less than 1 percent of its global work force of more than 1.5 million.

item.title: Lithium-Ion Batteries in E-Bikes and Other Devices Pose Fire Risks
item.description: The batteries, also found in phones, laptops, toothbrushes and other items, have caused about 200 fires and six deaths in New York City this year, fire officials say. Here’s what to know about safety.
item.dc:creator: April Rubin
item.media:description: On a production line of lithium ion batteries in China in 2018. The batteries power devices in cellphones, laptops, electric toothbrushes, power tools and electric vehicles.

item.title: Time Is Running Out for the Leap Second
item.description: To the world’s timekeepers, the leap second is a kludge, a bane, a pain in the little hand. Now they’re proposing to ditch it. Will our days ever be the same?
item.dc:creator: Alanna Mitchell
item.category: International Bureau of Weights and Measures
National Institute of Standards and Technology
item.media:description: “The Astronomer,” a 1668 painting by the Dutch painter Johannes Vermeer.

item.title: TikTok Builds Itself Into an Ads Juggernaut
item.description: The Chinese-owned video app’s ad business is thriving, even as a digital advertising slump hurts Meta, Snap and other rivals.
item.dc:creator: Kalley Huang, Isabella Simonetti and Tiffany Hsu
item.media:description: Screen shots of an ad, featuring Kate Bartlett, for Tiffany & Company on TikTok.

item.title: Internal Documents Show How Close the F.B.I. Came to Deploying Spyware
item.description: Christopher Wray, the F.B.I.’s director, told Congress last December that the bureau purchased the phone hacking tool Pegasus for research and development purposes.
item.dc:creator: Mark Mazzetti and Ronen Bergman
item.media:credit: Stefani Reynolds for The New York Times
item.media:description: Christopher A. Wray, the F.B.I. director, acknowledged that the bureau considered deploying the hacking tool.
